To clarify for those who haven't seen it, this is more tha=
n just a reprint of Albert Yamanaka's original work.  Paul Allman took apar=
t a set of the original newsletters and rearranged them according to a logi=
cal table of contents.  The first two volumes are as easily accessed as the=
 Nihonto Koza or similar encyclopedia.  

Volume I covers Koto, arranged by=
 the classical road system.

Volume II is Shinto and Shin-Shinto, followed =
by History of the Japanese Sword, Identification of Nihonto through Shape, =
and Definition of Nihonto and its Nomenclature.

Volume III includes Histor=
ical figures, Famous Swords in Japanese History, Kokuho, Missing Kokuho and=
 Juyo Bijutsu and Kyoho Meibutsu Cho

Volume IV continues Kyoho Meibutsu Ch=
o, several articles by others, the Tokugawa Jikki and an extensive compilat=
ion of Random Thoughts.

Some of the most interesting material is in later =
two volumes, but an index would greatly enhance their usability.

The Allma=
n version came out over ten years ago, but was "off the market" until recen=
tly.  I see that latest offering does not include binding of the four volum=
es, so be sure to get them into some sort of binding before the pages get m=
ixed up. 

Jim
